answers.answer: No one can tell what will happen in the future. Without the modern wonders of vitreous surgery he likely would have no sight. The most important thing is get the diabetes under meticuous control A1c less than 6.0  keep blood pressure, cholesterol, body weight at ideal levels and DO NOT SMOKE.Diabetes is a progressive disease so yes he could have more bleeding in the eye.JCH MD

question: My husband has proliferative retinopathy...we found out 1 year ago...so far he has had 4 laser surgeries in his right eye, he is legally blind in his left eye.  He had a vitrectomy in his right eye, about 2 months ago.  He is seeing ok in his right eye...Did the vitrectomy stop the blood "floaters" or is there a chance they will come back.  He is not in good control of his diabetes, type 1, so is there still a chance he could lose his sight.   What time frame are we talking about.  I hate to give him false hope if there is blindness at the end of this journey.thanks,michelle
